column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=5. Research Insights and Conclusions
#Text=This research provides insight from a pre- and post-occupancy longitudinal study of low-carbon development residents and with a focus on tracking the pre-occupancy practices of residents .

#Text=However , as this research has shown , an understanding of pre-occupancy practices allows an assessment of how resident practices change post-occupancy when interacting with the design and technological elements of a low-carbon development .
#Text=There were distinct changes in practice occurring when the technology changes in households .
#Text=Lower household water consumption levels are primarily due to low flow fixtures and a smaller garden to water .
#Text=Energy-efficient lights were also installed to reduce operational running costs of the home .
#Text=The changes in the technology used to heat and cool the home also influence the household energy use .
#Text=Reverse cycle air conditioners have less energy demand when running on the heating setting than gas or electric oil heaters when used to heat a large space .
#Text=Along with a change in technology used in the practice , a change in the skills of the resident performing the practice are also required .
#Text=This was highlighted through the personal hygiene practices of residents .
#Text=Those who had previously had access to a bath and used this for cleanliness and relaxation , post-occupancy had to rely on a shower to perform this task instead .
#Text=Some residents then changed their practice for relaxation to a visit to the beach .
#Text=The HSOP influence on household energy consumption patterns was outlined over two of the hottest weekdays and weekends of the monitoring period for three households with different routines .
#Text=The marked difference in energy use based on time of day and the practices being performed enable an understanding of the increase in renewable energy and battery storage options .

#Text=The HSOP and energy consumption patterns will often remain the same , regardless of where the energy is sourced from , which will be a consideration for builders and designers of low-carbon development and energy-efficient homes and technology .
#Text=As with any research , there are limitations to this study , although the authors have tried to minimise them where possible .
#Text=The limited sample size may have affected the wider implications of the study .
#Text=Residents who had not moved in to the low-carbon development by the beginning of 2019 were unable to participate .
#Text=Future research might include a larger sample size of residents in a low-carbon development to see how these early adopters interact with the design and technology .
#Text=The use of household level data was chosen to be able to assess the influence of the house as a system , in relation to the social practice theory development of a HSOP .
#Text=Without intensive monitoring of the residents , accurate individual energy and water use is difficult to estimate .
#Text=The authors did originally divide the household level data by the number of occupants in the household , but this resulted in discrepancies with the qualitative findings reported by residents .
#Text=For instance , household C had three adults pre-occupancy — two teenage sons and their mother .
#Text=The individual data showed high consumption levels per individual .

#Text=However , the interview revealed that the mother had low-energy and water consumption levels , while the sons would have long showers , use the tumble dryer , use their computers extensively and leave the lights on .
#Text=This highlights the intra home heterogeneity in the performance of practices .
#Text=There were a number of households pre-occupancy who did not have access to their energy or water consumption data , or the data they provided was only for a few months a year .
#Text=The authors chose not to use this incomplete data as it does not provide an accurate reflection of household energy and water consumption levels .
#Text=This has reduced the households with available pre-occupancy data and influenced the extent to which the authors could comment on the possible impact of rebound effects .
#Text=Future studies might aim to obtain more detailed energy and water data both pre- and post-occupancy to allow for this area of research to be explored .
#Text=This would allow for the statistical analysis of changes in energy and water consumption to be undertaken with confidence .
#Text=It may also provide an opportunity to consider other methods of analysis such as multi-criteria analysis or the model of recursive cultural adaptation .
